hedline.hl1: Color Choices for Headphones Make Them iMacs for the Ears

abstract.p: Sony offers lightweigh headphones for use with portable music devices that come with interchangeable shells in translucent colors; photo (S)

block.p: Just how far is all this Macintosh-inspired translucence going to go? Apparently, the design folks at Sony believe that the iMac look should be extended to their latest offering in lightweight headphones.

Just how far is all this Macintosh-inspired translucence going to go? Apparently, the design folks at Sony believe that the iMac look should be extended to their latest offering in lightweight headphones.

Called W.EAR (no, the period between the W and the E is not a typo), these cleverly crafted headphones, ideal for use with portable music devices, come with interchangeable shells in 12 translucent colors. Beneath their skins, the headphones, which cost $30 each and come with two sets of shells (extra shells cost $6 a pair), sport some impressive engineering. Sony spokesmen said that W.EAR headphones used highly efficient Neodymium magnets that help pump out 104 decibels of sound pressure from a single watt of input power. The W.EAR headphones also have a gold-plated plug at the end of the copper cord to reduce electrical resistance so the headphones can take the most advantage of whatever music player it happens to be plugged into.
